summary: In Rex v Joseph Olagbanye, the West African Court of Appeal dismissed the appellant's appeal against conviction for preparation of counterfeit coin under section 148(3)(c) and unlawful possession of counterfeit coin under section 152(3) of the Criminal Code. The original four-year sentences with hard labour were deemed inadequate given the prevalence of such crimes. The court quashed the original sentences and imposed enhanced concurrent sentences of seven years' imprisonment with hard labour, effective from 7th July, 1936.
citations: Rex v Joseph Olagbanye, WACA/3, 17th October 1986
rationaleHighlights: The appeal against conviction lacked merit and was dismissed.
The court found the original four-year sentences inadequate.
Sentences were enhanced to seven years due to the prevalence of counterfeiting crimes.
The enhanced sentences were to run concurrently and backdate to 7th July, 1936.
